Introduction

The purpose of this policy is to ensure that patients who attend MSE Foundation Trust (‘the Trust') for an operative procedure arrive at the relevant department having been fully prepared for the operative procedure that is to be undertaken.

In a service as large and complex as the NHS, there will be occasions when things do not go as planned. These include such events as wrong site, wrong procedure or wrong person surgery. These events are Never Events and should not occur under any circumstances.

This policy has been formulated in response to the recommendations made by the National Patient Safety Agency (NPSA) and is designed to complement the World Health Organisation (WHO) checklist implemented on 1 June 2009.

The policy has been formulated in response to the Department of Health publications Building a Safer NHS, Doing less Harm and the National Patient Safety Agency publications Building a memory: preventing harm, reducing risks and improving patient safety, and Seven Steps to Patient Safety. However, the ultimate aim is to reduce the risk of harm to patients through improving the safety and quality of services and the environment.
Scope
This policy applies to all staff who are involved in ensuring that patients are fully prepared for their surgical procedure.
All staff are provided with the training required to ensure that they are competent to escort patients to the allocated operating department or procedure room.

The Trust has the responsibility to ensure when the patients leave the ward that they are accompanied by all of the recognised Trust paperwork and prepared for their surgical procedure as per instruction on the Theatre Care Plan.

The Trust has a duty of care to always act in the patient's best interest, maintaining patient safety and ensuring that all patients follow a planned pathway of care once they are in the operating department/procedure room.
To ensure patients are transferred to the operating area safely at all times.
To provide guidelines that:
Minimise the risk of surgery on the wrong site or wrong patient
Minimise the risk of the wrong procedure being performed
Inform and guide the operating surgeon as to the method used to mark the skin and operative site
Where anatomically the site will be marked
When the marking will be undertaken.
This policy applies to all permanent, locum, agency and bank doctors or their deputies who undertake invasive procedures

data.text: Responsibilities within the Trust

Chief Executive – As the Trust's accountable officer has overall responsibility for ensuring Southend University Hospital Foundation Trust has robust, complete and up to date procedures in place to govern and guide activities so that legal, and national requirements are met.
Medical Director – The Medical Director has ultimate responsibility for ensuring that appropriate processes are in place for the safe management of surgical patients, including preoperative marking.
Clinical Director - Each Directorate Clinical Director has responsibility for ensuring their surgeons mark patients' accordingly and carry out the instructions within this policy.
Operating Surgeon (or deputy) – It is the responsibility of the operating surgeon or deputy to mark the operative site in accordance with this policy
Anaesthetists - must check the appropriate marking prior to any procedure or proposed local/regional block

The Operating Theatre Team - The operating theatre team must carry out the WHO Checklist. They have joint responsibility for ensuring that the correct site has been identified prior to commencement of surgery.
Senior Sisters are responsible for ensuring that staff are competent to safely prepare and transfer a patient to the operating area.
Patient Allocated Nurse should:
Ensure that the patient is correctly prepared for their surgery;
Sign the patient out of the ward using the checklist on the Theatre Care Plan, verifying that all relevant checks and paperwork have been completed;
The surgical site mark MUST BE verified as accurate as part of this checklist;
Ensure that the patient is correctly checked out of the ward and the patients details are handed over to the theatre escort;

Is responsible for the patient's safe transfer. If the patient requires nursing care during the transfer then the registered practitioner must escort the patient to theatre with the theatre escort and handover the care of the patient to the operating department practitioner in the anaesthetic room;
4.8.1  Patient Allocated Nurse must ensure that the patient has all of the following paperwork:
Correct and completed consent form;
Completed Anaesthetic sheet;
Prescription Chart;
Theatre Care Plan;
Patient's hospital notes.
X-Rays and any other additional reports;
Relevant blood and other test results e.g. MRSA swab result;
The surgical grid and photograph is required for skin cancer patient's surgery patients in plastic surgery.
Healthcare Support Workers who are required to escort patients to the operating theatre/procedure room must be assessed as competent to do so.

Theatre Support Workers with approved competency can escort patients who meet the criteria to be transferred without a registered nurse escort to the identified theatre area (this may be the holding bay in recovery or the named anaesthetic room).
Operating schedule:
The operating lists are delivered by a nominated person from theatre reception to the wards the night before surgery is scheduled. Wards are able to access Theatreman.
Southend Hospital Theatre lists are generated via Sapphire and all wards access the operating lists via this system.
Patients are identified on an operating list that is supplied by theatres to the wards.
The theatre receptionist will generate another operating list if there are any amendments to the operating lists that have been made;
The minor ops
Pre-operative marking mandatory requirements
The surgical site should be marked on the ward or admitting area prior to the patient's transfer to the operating theatre or minor ops area.

Marking should be carried out after all the available information concerning the patient's identity, the procedure and the surgical site/intended side (provided by the patient's notes, consent etc.) has been checked and cross referenced.
Marking must take place before sedative pre-medication is administered.
Which Sites to Mark
5.4.1  Must be made with an indelible marker that remains visible after preparation of the patient's operation site.
Surgical Site marking applies, as a minimum, to all cases of incision or percutaneous intervention involving laterality:
Single limb;
One of a pair of organs;
Specific lesion;
Specific digit(s) (finger or toe);

Spine level (vertebrae). For spinal surgery the advice is for a 2 stage marking process where, firstly the general level of the procedure is marked preoperatively: cervical, thoracic, lumbar. The surgical site is then marked to show either posterior or anterior approach with right or left being highlighted. Secondly, the exact interspace(s) are demonstrated using standard intra-operative radiographic marking technique.

5.5.1  The mark should extend to the incision site. The site should be labelled with text identifying that site which is to be operated upon and in addition a mark or arrow is applied. For example left knee
Hand trauma patients

5.6.1  The digit(s) should be clearly marked with an arrow drawn as close as possible to the base of the digit(s) on the dorsal AND volar aspects of the hand. There should also be a clear “dot” marked on the end of the digit(s), unless the tip is injured or covered by dressings. If the patient is having surgery to a specific joint, the joint should be marked with an “X”, in addition to the other markings required.
Dental extractions

5.7.1 It is acknowledged that there is no practical or reliable way of marking teeth or mucous membrane. Alternative methods must be used to confirm the intended site; review of the dental records, medical history, laboratory tests, dental charts and x- rays.

5.7.2 The number of teeth to be removed/involved must be indicated on the chart or x- ray. Verification that x-rays and visual identification of the correct teeth/tissues is confirmed as part of the WHO Check.

5.7.3 Where possible the number of the tooth/teeth should be written on the cheek on the corresponding side with a line either above or below to indicate top or bottom jaw. For full dental clearance an X should be used instead of numbers to indicate all teeth.

5.7.4 Skin Lesions/lumps must be specifically marked i.e. lesions /lumps must be circled. Where this is not possible an arrow may be used to pinpoint exact site. Patients should have accompanying photos and grid marking.
5.7.5 (Refer to Appendix 1 and 2)
5.7.6 Other sites that may require marking are those necessary for some other aspects of care that directly relates to the planned procedure; dual/multiple surgical sites, donor site, stoma site.
Ophthalmology

5.8.1  For single eye surgery a small mark should be made either on the temple or on the lateral aspect of the eye between the lateral canthus and the ear pointing to the correct eye for treatment. The exception is for planned bilateral procedures on both eyes (such as bilateral squint) but the laterality of such procedures should be well documented. The marking of a child's face/head must be assessed at the time of assessment by the surgeon as to its psychological appropriateness. If no mark is made, then the clinician in charge of the case is responsible for assessing the situation with the patient and will decide whether it is safe to continue with the procedure or to cancel and reschedule. Any changes must be agreed with the patient and/or patients advocate / patients parent or guardian and the surgical team and documented in patients records
Who marks

5.9.1  Marking should be undertaken by the operating surgeon/practitioner or nominated deputy who is a competent member of the surgical team who will be present in the operating theatre at the time of surgery.
Anaesthetic blocks

5.10.1  The responsibility for the site marking remains with the operating surgeon. Where a regional anaesthetic block is planned it will be the responsibility of the anaesthetist performing the block to mark the site of the proposed block (STOP BEFORE YOU
BLOCK )and document this on the anaesthetic chart (refer to Appendix 3). The site of the marking should be confirmed by a second practitioner.
With whom
5.11.1 The process of pre-operative marking of the intended site should involve the patient and or significant others/family members as required.

5.11.2 The patient always has the right to refuse marking. In the event of a patient refusing pre-operative site marking the surgeon in charge must assess the situation and either return the patient to the ward or note and sign a decision to proceed. This should be handled in the same way as for any other refusal of treatment. The responsibility of the person marking the site is to provide the patient with information as to why site marking is required as well as the implications of refusing site marking. Then the patient can make an informed decision. The duty of the person marking the site is to ensure that the refusal is documented in the patient's notes.
5.11.3 Exceptions to marking as follows:
All endoscopies;
Procedures where there is no predetermined site of surgical access i.e. cardiac catheterisation;
Procedures on midline structures such as umbilical, perineal and anal areas and also procedures such as circumcision, hypospadias repair, cleft palate;
Single organs i.e. uterus, bladder, appendix;
Other areas where it is anatomically or technically difficult to mark the operative site includes perineum, friable skin around a site, burns, neonates, premature infants;

Site marking is not required in the obvious case of wounds, defects (e.g. cleft lip repair, nasal reconstruction) or lesions if this wound or lesion is the site of the intended procedure. However if there are multiple wounds or lesions but only some must be treated, these sites must be marked.
Verification

5.12.1 The surgical site mark should subsequently be checked against the consent form to confirm it is: a) correctly located and b) legible. This check should occur as part of the WHO checklist for patients undergoing surgery/procedure. For ward based patients this must be completed prior to the patient leaving the ward.

5.12.2 All site markings must be made in conjunction with checks made on the patient's diagnostic imaging results; i.e. x-rays, scans, electronic imaging or other appropriate test results ensuring that these match the patients' medical notes and name band.
5.12.3 This check must be undertaken by a registered nurse/practitioner who is managing the patient's care.
Transfer of patients to operating theatre
All patients are required to be prepared and ready for theatre prior to their transfer.
Patients are transferred to the operating area from the ward on their own bed, trolley or by foot.
On entering the operating theatre environment patients are to be checked in using the WHO checklist (WHO Procedure 18017).
Parents and guardians of children undergoing surgery
Children that require surgery will be placed on a specialist paediatric ward/day stay Unit.

All children may be escorted to the operating theatre by a parent, an appointed guardian or a nominated individual over the age of 18 who can confirm the signature of the parent/guardian, supported by an allocated member of staff.
The guardian/parent will remain with the child in the anaesthetic room until the child is asleep and will then be escorted from the room by the accompanying member of staff.
Breaches of the procedure
Any breach must be notified on Datix particularly incidents such as:
Patients not ready for theatre leading to operating list delays;
Patients late for theatre due to there being problems releasing staff to escort;
Theatres must report any discrepancy relating to patient identification.
Training
All staff employed by the Anaesthetic and Theatre Department receives full training in the transfer of patients from the wards to the Operating Theatre Department.
Anaesthetic and theatre staff has approved competencies to ensure that patients receive safe care in accordance with Trust Guidelines.
The Anaesthetic and Theatre Department have assessed that all staff have achieved CNST competencies in their area of work.
All staff should complete the generic competency for their band.
Monitoring and audit
The Trust's central Governance department review all incidents reported on Datix and monitor anything that impacts on patient safety.

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Anaesthetic and Theatres Governance Department , which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local policies and guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform Divisions leads of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and meets the needs of all individuals.
